comments.body: nit: Typically correlationId is positive. Does this have a purpose?

Yeah, this is done in multiple places.  For example, twice in `SocketServerTest` (which is where I got the approach from):

https://github.com/apache/kafka/blob/trunk/core/src/test/scala/unit/kafka/network/SocketServerTest.scala#L167
https://github.com/apache/kafka/blob/trunk/core/src/test/scala/unit/kafka/network/SocketServerTest.scala#L687

Twice in `EdgeCaseRequestTest`:
https://github.com/apache/kafka/blob/trunk/core/src/test/scala/unit/kafka/server/EdgeCaseRequestTest.scala#L85
https://github.com/apache/kafka/blob/trunk/core/src/test/scala/unit/kafka/server/EdgeCaseRequestTest.scala#L115

And actually once in non-test code (`AuthorizerUtils`)
https://github.com/apache/kafka/blob/trunk/core/src/main/scala/kafka/security/authorizer/AuthorizerUtils.scala#L91

I do note that the Correlation ID is documented as an integer as opposed to a _positive_ one (https://cwiki.apache.org/confluence/display/KAFKA/A+Guide+To+The+Kafka+Protocol#AGuideToTheKafkaProtocol-Requests).

It feels to me that if this is an issue that needs to be fixed then it might require a separate ticket (especially since there is a non-test occurrence).

We're generally ok with micro-cleanups here and there as part of a bug fix, especially since the follow-ups tend not to happen. I see it as akin to the scout's rule of leaving the campground cleaner than how you found it. Anyway, it's not an actual problem; I just thought it was odd.
